author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Celebrates Joe Biden’s ‘Joe-mentum’
description: The Democratic presidential contender leads President Trump in a new poll, but Stephen Colbert and Seth Meyers suggested that the former vice president stay in his basement to help ensure a win.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Summer’s Here, and America Is Ready to Quarancheat
description: Can you trust your loved ones to enjoy reopenings responsibly?
content: The first weekend in June, Cyré Olivia Coleman, 29, a student in Randolph, Mass., did something that even a month earlier would have felt like a far-fetched dream: took a family vacation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pooja Makhijani
title: How to Handle a Mom-Friend Breakup
description: Those bonds forged when you have babies don’t always last.
content: L and I connected online, as pregnant women sometimes do. I began reading her blog, and she mine. We met at a downtown café, where we shared a waffle with ice cream, a few weeks after exchanging our first emails. During our pregnancies, we went to the same prenatal education classes — birthing, breastfeeding, infant first aid. We swapped yoga and baby-wearing and infant-clothing resources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: A Virus Walks Into a Bar …
description: As communities open up, it’s becoming increasingly clear that the indoor bar scene is uniquely suited to transmission of Covid-19.
content: Everything you love about your neighborhood bar — the ambience, the crowds, the music, the free-flowing alcohol — makes it the ideal place to catch Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: When the Louvre Reopens, It’s Going to Be Quiet
description: The museum’s president said visitor numbers could be reduced as much as 80 percent. That might mean a better view of the Mona Lisa, if you can get there.
content: The Musée du Louvre in Paris is set to reopen on July 6 after a 16-week shutdown that has taken a 40-million-euro toll on its bottom line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: U.S.T.A. Reinstates U.S. Open Wheelchair Tournament
description: The tournament’s original framework released last week eliminated the competition, a decision many wheelchair players said had been made without consulting them.
content: After an outcry from players, the United States Tennis Association has restored the wheelchair tennis competition to the 2020 United States Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Global economy, Europe’s past politicianry, TikTok: Here’s what you need to know.
content: China is testing restaurant workers and delivery drivers block by block. South Korea tells people to carry two types of masks for different risky social situations. Britain is targeting local outbreaks in a strategy that Prime Minister Boris Johnson calls “Whac-a-Mole.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kortemeier and Naomi Shihab Nye
title: Poem: Surveillance
description: We’re being collected somewhere on video and in memory — and maybe we want to be.
content: “Ganbatte” is Japanese for “hold out, persevere, do your best.” In the spring of 2020, those concepts took on new meaning for everyone — as did the concept of donning a ski mask and jumping through any door. Sarah Kortemeier’s poem from her mesmerizing debut collection, “Ganbatte,” offers a new twist on vigilance. We’re being collected somewhere on video and in memory, at all times, and maybe we want to be. Balcony waves are not quite enough. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This week’s properties include a six-bedroom in Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Fairfield, Conn.
content: This week’s properties include a six-bedroom in Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Fairfield, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Pina
title: N.B.A. Ironmen Cling to Routine During the Load Management Era
description: A small faction of players — less than 4 percent in the 2018-19 season — play in all 82 games in a season. They have had to adjust to some rare downtime with the N.B.A. shut down by the pandemic.
content: Little will be ordinary when the abbreviated 2019-20 N.B.A. season resumes as expected on July 30. Games will be played at the Walt Disney World Resort inside a so-called bubble, a plan that does away with playoff basketball’s normal hallmarks of rigorous travel, home-court advantage and the motivational fuel provided by screaming fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Granville
title: Wirecard, Reeling From Accounting Scandal, Files for Insolvency
description: The German electronic payments company, where $2.1 billion went missing, cited “impending insolvency and over-indebtedness.”
content: Wirecard, the troubled German company that became embroiled in a scandal over a missing $2.1 billion, said on Thursday that it would file for insolvency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Arizona ‘Overwhelmed’ With Demand for Tests as U.S. System Shows Strain
description: American coronavirus testing remains fragmented, as in the early days of the pandemic, and the bottlenecks are the same ones, too.
content: People seeking drive-up coronavirus tests in Phoenix faced a three-mile-long car line last weekend. On Friday, Arizona’s largest laboratory received twice as many samples as it could process. The phone line for testing appointments at a large site on the state fairgrounds now opens at 7 a.m. with 800 callers already in the queue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Black-White Wage Gap Is as Big as It Was in 1950
description: Recent research indicates little progress since the Truman administration.
content: That’s remarkable. Despite decades of political change — the end of enforced segregation across the South, the legalization of interracial marriage, the passage of multiple civil rights laws and more — the wages of black men trail those of white men by as much as when Harry Truman was president. That gap indicates that there have also been powerful forces pushing against racial equality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Labour’s New Leader Sacks Official Over Charges of Anti-Semitism
description: Keir Starmer dismissed a hard-left member of the so-called shadow cabinet after she had shared an article that, without evidence, tied Israel to tactics used in George Floyd’s killing.
content: LONDON — In a decisive break with the hard-left wing of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, its new leader dismissed a senior lawmaker on his leadership team Thursday for having shared an article online that the party said contained an anti-Semitic conspiracy theory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Some of France’s Only Live Theater Right Now Is a Historical Affront
description: A theme park’s whiz-bang performances are an odd mix of high-quality production values and one-dimensional storytelling. Historians have long disputed the narratives.
content: LES EPESSES, France — While most French theaters remain closed and live sports won’t resume until July, there is one arena in the country where thousands can already sit down to watch a show. In a Roman-style amphitheater at the Puy du Fou, a historical theme park in western France, gladiators in period costumes have been performing daily since June 11.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: School by Zoom might have been weird and compromised and unsatisfying, true. But now that it’s over and summer looms menacingly ahead with nothing but question marks for parents and kids — Is camp really safe? What about a job at the local mall or movie theater? What are we supposed to doooooo all day? — books are here to help. (Books are always here to help.) For the teens and tweens in my house, distraction has come lately by way of Jonathan Waldman and Rainbow Rowell and Pam Muñoz Ryan; for the parents and kids together, it’s come by way of nightly read-alouds from Philip Pullman’s “His Dark Materials” trilogy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Wilson
title: Leo Tolstoy vs. the Police
description: Why the great Russian novelist’s critique of state-sponsored violence bears thinking about now.
content: In the early months of lockdown, many people stuck at home found themselves turning to unusual sources of comfort: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s PowerPoint presentations, bread-baking (especially, for reasons unclear, sourdough) and “War and Peace,” Leo Tolstoy’s 1,200-page novel about the Napoleonic era in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: The Ending of This Louisa May Alcott Story May Disappoint You
description: “Aunt Nellie’s Diary” was penned by the famous author when she was only 17. It has been published for the first time in The Strand Magazine.
content: A previously unpublished piece by Louisa May Alcott, the author best known for her novel “Little Women,” is now available in print for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Mahler
title: A Governor on Her Own, With Everything at Stake
description: From her living room, Gretchen Whitmer has led Michigan through a pandemic, an economic meltdown and even a dam collapse — all at a time when government itself seems broken.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Disney’s Splash Mountain to Drop ‘Song of the South’ Depictions
description: The popular log flume ride will be remade around “The Princess and the Frog,” the 2009 musical that introduced Disney’s first black princess.
content: LOS ANGELES — So long, Splash Mountain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Study Raises Concerns for Pregnant Women With the Coronavirus
description: Pregnant women who are infected wind up in hospitals and I.C.U.’s at higher rates, a federal analysis suggests. But the data is far from conclusive.
content: Pregnant women infected with the coronavirus are more likely to be hospitalized, admitted to an intensive care unit and put on a ventilator than are infected women who are not pregnant, according to a new government analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Dentists Are Reopening, but Should Patients Go Back?
description: Dentists are donning head-to-toe protective equipment, switching to laser instruments and taking other steps to reassure patients that it’s safe to get back in the chair.
content: At Dr. Todd Bertman’s office, the receptionist wears a plastic face shield. So do the hygienist and the nine doctors in the practice in Manhattan’s East Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Defense Secretary Faces White House Pressure on Aides and a Military Promotion
description: Senior Defense Department personnel who are perceived as White House critics are resigning or facing reprisal.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is facing a hemorrhage of talent as senior officials resign amid continued efforts by the White House to purge those perceived as political foes, including the Army lieutenant colonel who testified in the House impeachment hearings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: U.S. Postpones Balkan Peace Summit, in Blow to Trump Foreign Policy
description: The White House had planned to host the presidents of Serbia and Kosovo on Saturday. Then Kosovo’s leader was charged with war crimes.
content: BERLIN — An American-mediated initiative to stabilize the Balkans, which the Trump administration hoped might burnish its foreign policy credentials in an election year, was postponed on Thursday after one of the main participants, President Hashim Thaci of Kosovo, was indicted on war crimes charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Popper
title: Disgraced Lobbyist Jack Abramoff Headed Back to Jail
description: Mr. Abramoff became the first person charged with violating a law that was amended in response to his previous criminal offenses.
content: Jack Abramoff, the disgraced lobbyist whose corruption became a symbol of the excesses of Washington influence peddling, is set to return to jail for violating the law that was amended in response to his earlier crimes, law enforcement officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: When the Toppled Statue Is of Your Great-Great-Great-Grandfather
description: Descendants of Robert E. Lee and others whose statues are coming down are confronting this moment’s reassessment of history in a very personal way.
content: Clayton Wickham, 28, said he used to think of the statue of his great-great-great-grandfather as “just a statue that had my name on it that was kind of cool to walk by every now and then.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Says Rejected Asylum Seekers Have No Right to Object in Court
description: The case concerned a member of Sri Lanka’s Tamil ethnic minority who said he feared persecution and sought to file a petition for a writ of habeas corpus.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court sided on Thursday with the Trump administration’s efforts to speed the deportation of asylum seekers, ruling that a law limiting the role of federal courts in reviewing those decisions was constitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: With Unemployment Offices Busy, Recovery Seems a ‘Long Haul’
description: As coronavirus hot spots flare across the U.S., adding to economic worries, new jobless claims surpassed one million for the 14th week.
content: As American businesses reopen in fits and starts — and anxiety over new coronavirus hot spots increases — state unemployment offices still have their hands full.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Kentucky Derby to Allow Spectators in September
description: The plan encourages guests and staff at Churchill Downs to wear masks, wash their hands and keep their distance from one another in the stands and in the barns.
content: The Kentucky Derby — known for its atmosphere as much as its thoroughbred racing — is keeping its fans this year for betting, mint juleps, and to see and be seen with elaborate millinery and seersucker suits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Trims Early Preseason Game and Prepares for Training Camps
description: Team owners canceled the annual Hall of Fame Game, but held firm on opening training camps in July and the regular season in September.
content: The N.F.L. on Thursday canceled its annual Hall of Fame Game, an exhibition scheduled for Aug. 6, so players and coaches grappling with restrictions related to the coronavirus pandemic could have more time to prepare for the regular season, which, for now, is still set to begin Sept. 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: Coronavirus Is a Crisis. Might It Also Narrow Inequality?
description: Economic downturns have often led to political moves to lift the most vulnerable. But recoveries tend to reverse the effect.
content: The United States faces an economic downturn without precedent. Is it also a moment that could produce lasting change?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: The Dixie Chicks Change Their Name, Dropping the ‘Dixie’
description: The platinum-selling country trio will be known as the Chicks, the latest example of sweeping cultural changes brought on by nationwide protests spotlighting racial inequality.
content: The Dixie Chicks are now the Chicks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Jenny Slate and Kristen Bell Leave Voice Roles as Black Characters
description: The actresses say the parts on “Big Mouth” and “Central Park” should have gone to people of color, and creators of the animated shows have apologized.
content: Two white actresses who voiced black characters on popular animated television shows announced that they would step down on Wednesday, extending a season of soul searching over systemic racism that has touched multiple industries in the wake of recent police killings of African-Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: A great comedy on Showtime returns after having its season cut short by the pandemic. A chill animated favorite is back, too, based on a popular series of children’s books.
content: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Theater Streams Make Room for Molière (and Imelda Marcos)
description: The online bounty also includes a rare Lorraine Hansberry play, two Lincoln Center stagings and black British responses to the killing of George Floyd.
content: In the BC era (Before Covid-19), theater lovers tended to eye screens warily. Now, we browse the Broadway HD catalog, scout YouTube for obscure European webcasts and text each other the link to Lin-Manuel Miranda’s 14-minute musical “21 Chump Street.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Search Party’ and ‘The Twilight Zone’
description: “Search Party” is back, now on HBO Max. And the second season of “The Twilight Zone” debuts on CBS All Access.
content: SEARCH PARTY Stream on HBO Max. “Could these hipsters be coldblooded murderers?” That question is posed by a news anchor in a trailer for the new, third season of this dark comedy series. The show stars Alia Shawkat as Dory, a millennial who lives in Brooklyn. The first season followed her and a group of fellow Brooklynites investigating a disappearance; the second season involved a killing. After a couple years off, Dory and company are back, this time on HBO’s new streaming service (the show was on TBS). Season 3 includes a high-stakes criminal trial, chic clothes and cynicism. “‘Search Party,’ has always had a retro-tinged aesthetic, a slight thrift-store defect to its world, which makes it feel surreal at times — part of reality but not identical to it,” Margaret Lyons wrote in a recent edition of The New York Times’s Watching newsletter. “Teasing out the contrast between the weightlessness of an imagined, curated past and the cruel density of the flawed, lived past is one of the show’s most elegant tricks.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘A Regular Woman’ Review: A Family Murder, as Told by the Victim
description: Sherry Hormann’s new film dramatizes a 2005 “honor killing” in Berlin, using a fictionalized version of the woman who died as narrator.
content: The drama “A Regular Woman” depicts the true story of Hatun Surucu — known to her friends as Aynur — a German woman of Turkish-Kurdish descent who was shot and killed by her brother in 2005. (The brother who pulled the trigger pleaded guilty in German courts, while two different brothers were recently acquitted of the crime, a so-called honor killing that made international news and inspired an earlier 2011 film.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Ella Fitzgerald: Just One of Those Things’ Review: Words Without Much Music
description: This documentary from Leslie Woodhead gives the first lady of song a dry, PBS-ready treatment.
content: “Ella Fitzgerald: Just One of Those Things” salutes the singer who became known as the first lady of song — whose six-decade career stretched from the comforts of novelty tunes to the cutting edge of jazz — with a PBS-ready treatment. It proceeds dryly and largely chronologically through her life, sometimes with an awkward sense of proportion. (Is it necessary for a full closing title card to note that Fitzgerald, who died in 1996, had both legs amputated toward the end of her life?)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Catie Edmondson
title: Police Groups Wield Strong Influence in Congress, Resisting the Strictest Reforms
description: Law enforcement groups, which have donated generously to members of both political parties, have dictated the terms of the debate on an overhaul, prodding lawmakers to reject the toughest measures.
content: WASHINGTON — As Americans were clamoring in the streets last week to defund the police and as Democrats in Congress were drafting legislation to make it easier to track and prosecute officer misconduct, Larry Cosme, a leader of the police lobby, was at the White House making a direct appeal to some of President Trump’s top advisers against some of the most consequential reforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Peyser
title: In Vintage TV Ads, a Curious Fountain of Hope (and Cheese)
description: An unlikely source of comfort viewing, YouTube compilations of old commercials have provided the writer a strange kind of optimism when so much else seems broken.
content: At the end of yet another long day indoors, when I want to unwind, I’ll put on the commercial breaks from the 1985 American Music Awards or CBS’s May 3, 1983, broadcast of “The Hunchback of Notre Dame.” I am transported to a magical time, full of smiling faces and hokey jingles, when you could buy a new car for less than $10,000 and Kraft had a line of “Casino” cheeses that were extra mild, in case regular Kraft cheese was too flavorful for you.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the Virus Won
description: Invisible outbreaks sprang up everywhere. The United States ignored the warning signs. We reconstructed how the epidemic spun out of control.

title: Who Are the Key Voters Turning Against Trump?
description: They’re senior voters, and they could be Joe Biden’s secret weapon.
content: Joe Biden may be ahead in national and many battleground polls, but Democrats are still fretting about whether key constituencies will turn out in November. In particular, they worry about the level of support from young black and Hispanic voters — for good reason.

title: As New Coronavirus Cases Hit Another Record in the U.S., Some States Delay Reopenings
description: The U.S. reported more than 41,000 new cases on Thursday, the second consecutive day with a record total, and the C.D.C. said the true national caseload was probably 10 times the official count. India plans to test all 29 million residents of its capital for the virus.
content: The United States on Thursday reported more than 41,000 new coronavirus cases, a record  total for the second straight day, as a nationwide sense of urgency grew and caseloads soared in Southern and Western states that were far removed from the worst early outbreaks.

title: Photographing the Beauty of My Mother’s Decline

title: When Bosses Shared Their Profits
description: Since the 1980s, profit-sharing has declined. It deserves to make a comeback.
content: After the bruising crises we’re now going through, it would be wonderful if we could somehow emerge a fairer nation. One possibility is to revive an old idea: sharing the profits.

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Want to Be in Stacey Abrams’s Book Club? Sorry, It’s Family Only
description: The best-selling author and former minority leader for the Georgia House of Representatives has a lot going on, but she still makes time for fiction.
content: WOMAN OF WORDS The last thing Stacey Abrams, who is a Democrat, wanted to do was write a memoir about losing the 2018 Georgia gubernatorial race to the Republican, Brian Kemp. She says the idea came up, but “it was not appealing to me. As someone who has spent my adult life working on issues of access, justice and voting rights, I wanted to figure out, what could I say that was necessary? That told readers, here’s what we have to know, so history doesn’t repeat itself. I come from a family where our parents told us, if you see a problem, your job is to fix it. Writing is how I work through how to fix it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Henderson
title: The Rebel Physicist Trying to Fix Quantum Mechanics
description: For a century, quantum theory has been scientific orthodoxy. The Italian physicist Angelo Bassi is certain it isn’t the full story — and that he can prove it.
content: ‘The thing that amazes me is that quantum mechanics is only 100 years old,” the physicist Angelo Bassi said. We were in conversation across a picnic table on a drab Soviet-era campus in Zagreb, an early-autumn breeze swishing through the yellowing leaves of some nearby trees. “It’s a baby, it’s nothing — 100 years in the history of science. How can you just stop there? It doesn’t make sense any way you look at it.” We sat in the shadow of a rust-stained beige building where Bassi was about to speak at a workshop for physicists who specialize in the century-old subject.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How We Got Here: Writers on Race and Racism in America
description: Amid the most profound social upheaval since the 1960s, these novelists, historians, poets, comedians and activists take a moment to look back to the literature.
content: Almost 100 years ago, responding to the public outcry over the violent drowning of a black boy by a white mob at a public beach on Lake Michigan, a citywide (multiracial but white-led) commission published “The Negro in Chicago: A Study of Race Relations and a Race Riot.”

title: More Adults Than Ever Live With Parents or Grandparents
description: Generation Zers who returned home in March and April represent about $726 million in lost monthly rental revenue, according to a new report.
content: A record 32 million American adults were living with their parents or grandparents in April, according to the latest American Community Survey from the U.S. Census Bureau, an increase of 9.7 percent over a year ago. The data, analyzed by Zillow researchers, showed that 2.7 million adults moved back home in March and April, and that about 2.2 million of them were aged 18 to 25 — also known as Generation Z.

title: Flare-up in Virus Cases Sets Back Germany’s Efforts to Reopen
description: Regional authorities have locked down two counties for the first time since the country’s broader reopening, which had been considered a success.
content: BERLIN — A spike of more than 1,500 coronavirus infections within days has dealt a sudden blow to Germany’s efforts to reopen the country, calling into question the durability of what had been widely considered a success story in managing the contagion in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: 22 Police Officers Injured in Scuffles at Illegal London Block Party
description: Officers were attacked as they attempted to break up an outdoor crowd in the southern district of Brixton, the police said.
content: At least 22 police officers were injured in South London on Wednesday night as they tried to disperse crowds that had gathered for an illegal outdoor party in defiance of coronavirus restrictions, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: This College Football Team Had No Coronavirus Cases at First. Then It Shut Down.
description: A spike in positive coronavirus tests is prompting universities across college sports to acknowledge how precarious their plans are for a season.
content: When Kansas State opened the doors to its athletic facilities, welcoming its football players back to campus starting the first weekend in June, administrators breathed a sigh of relief once the first batch of coronavirus tests came back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: N.Y.P.D. Officer Charged With Using Illegal Chokehold
description: The officer, shown in a video with his arm around a man’s neck, is the first in the city to face felony charges under a new law banning officers from using chokeholds.
content: A New York City police officer was arrested on Thursday morning and charged with illegally using a chokehold to subdue a man on the boardwalk at a Queens beach, becoming the first city officer to be charged under a new state law making it a felony for the police to use such holds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Ben Hubbard
title: Israel Announces Partnership With U.A.E., Which Throws Cold Water On It
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu touted a rare public opening between the two countries. Apparently, the Emirates was not ready for it.
content: TEL AVIV, Israel — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel announced a new partnership with the United Arab Emirates on Thursday to cooperate in the fight against the coronavirus, portraying it as the latest advance in the Jewish state’s efforts to build stronger ties with Arab states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Andrew Das
title: Australia and New Zealand Will Host 2023 Women’s World Cup
description: The joint hosting arrangement would be the first for women’s soccer’s biggest championship, which will expand to 32 teams for the event.
content: Australia and New Zealand will serve as co-hosts for the 2023 Women’s World Cup, FIFA announced Thursday, sending one of its two biggest tournaments — and its first 32-team women’s championship — to two nations that have embraced the women’s game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: A Historic Heat Wave Roasts Siberia
description: Wildfires are spreading. The mosquitoes are ravenous. People are shielding their windows from the midnight sun with foil and blankets.
content: MOSCOW — They used to ride snowmobiles in June in Russkoye Ustye, a Siberian village by the Arctic Ocean coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Jay Clayton, Would-Be Prosecutor, Says He’s Focused on His Current Job
description: Mr. Clayton, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, answered questions from House Democrats about his unusual nomination to be the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan.
content: Jay Clayton is not withdrawing his nomination as the next federal prosecutor in Manhattan, but he doesn’t plan to give up his day job as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission anytime soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Five Months After Celebrating the Economy in Wisconsin, Trump Returns to a Different Place
description: At a shipyard on Lake Michigan, the president played up the economic benefits of a new Navy contract.
content: Five months ago, President Trump fired up thousands of fans at a campaign rally in Milwaukee with a boastful question for a state he barely won in 2016: “How are your 401(k)’s doing?” he bellowed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: Momentum for an Effort to Save Children From Sweltering Cars
description: The Hot Cars Act of 2019 is part of legislation the House will soon consider. It’s long overdue, say advocates of technology that alerts owners.
content: There was reason for optimism last June. The Hot Cars Act of 2019 appeared to be making some progress. The bill would require a device that could warn drivers and car owners of a child left behind in a car or one who had gotten into a parked car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: John J. Mooney, an Inventor of the Catalytic Converter, Dies at 90
description: The device he developed with a colleague in the 1970s has prevented billions of tons of carbon emissions from being spewed by cars, trucks and lawn mowers.
content: John J. Mooney, an inventor of the catalytic converter, the small and ubiquitous device that makes the engines that power everything from cars to lawn mowers less polluting and more fuel efficient, died on June 16 at his home in Wyckoff, N.J. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our culture writers offer suggestions for what to watch or listen to, and how to celebrate Pride Month as it winds down.
content: In recent years, at least two major Pride events in New York could be described as part dance party, part arts happening: Everybooty at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and the House Party at New York Live Arts. This year, when both organizations had to figure out how to celebrate community in a time of social distancing, they decided to make a bigger noise by going online together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: A Full View, at Last, of Modern Art in South Korea
description: “Korean Art From 1953,” a lavish new book, is the most significant English-language overview yet of modern and contemporary art on the peninsula.
content: Many rich nations use art, music and movies to project an image to the world, but few take it as seriously as South Korea — today’s uncontested champion of cultural soft power. In the last 20 years, the nation’s singers and actors have thumped to Asian and then worldwide superstardom — signaled in 2012 by the viral amusement “Gangnam Style” (the first song to hit a billion views on YouTube); strengthened by the stadium-filling concerts of BTS, Loona and other K-pop bands; and capped recently by the unprecedented best picture Oscar for Bong Joon Ho’s “Parasite.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Still Reeling From Oil Plunge, Texas Faces New Threat: Surge in Virus Cases
description: Businesses were reopening in recent weeks and oil prices had climbed north of $40 a barrel before coronavirus infections accelerated in the state.
content: HOUSTON — Things were looking up for Texas in recent weeks. Oil prices had managed an impressive rebound, more than doubling to just above $40 a barrel. Restaurants and small businesses were opening up in Houston, Dallas and elsewhere. And tens of thousands of people were getting back to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: $1.4 Billion in Stimulus Funds Sent to Dead People, Watchdog Finds
description: A Government Accountability Office report said the Treasury and the Internal Revenue Service failed to consult death records, resulting in improper payments.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration delivered more than a million stimulus payments worth about $1.4 billion to dead people in a rush to pump money into the economy this year, the Government Accountability Office said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Does Cinéma Vérité Exist? Watch These 2 Movies to Find Out
description: The documentary style is eye-opening as it tests the boundaries of nonfiction filmmaking. Try “Crisis” and “Salesman” to start.
content: For a genre that ostensibly presents snippets of unvarnished truth, a particular type of documentary is difficult to name. The opening of “Chronicle of a Summer” (1961), a groundbreaking example by the anthropologist Jean Rouch and the sociologist Edgar Morin, calls it “cinéma vérité.” To the brothers Albert and David Maysles, it was “direct cinema.” Frederick Wiseman has used the phrase “reality fictions.” But in a 2015 interview, he told me he meant that term in jest: If Truman Capote could describe “In Cold Blood” as a nonfiction novel, then surely Wiseman could say his own films — shot unobtrusively, then edited with an eye toward characterization — added a novelistic spin to reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Irresistible’ Review: The Voters Are Red, the Message Is Blue
description: Jon Stewart’s new political satire, which presents a homespun cliché of Middle America, is a lecture on old news.
content: East Coast slickness meets heartland folksiness in “Irresistible,” a political satire so broad and blunt that it flattens every joke and deflates every setup. Movies like this should skip and jab; instead, this second feature from the writer and director Jon Stewart (after his impressively accomplished prison drama, “Rosewater,” in 2014) lumbers and flails. Set shortly after the 2016 election, it feels like an artifact from a particularly contentious past, a stale corn chip trampled into Party-convention carpeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: Trump Family Will Ask Second Court to Stop Publication of Tell-All Book
description: A Queens County, N.Y., judge said his court lacked jurisdiction in the case.
content: A Queens County, N.Y., Surrogate’s Court judge on Thursday rejected a request to bar President Trump’s niece, Mary L. Trump, from publishing a tell-all book about the family because the court lacked jurisdiction in the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘All I Can Say’ Review: A Rock Star Captures His Own Rise and Fall
description: This new documentary is assembled from voluminous footage shot by Shannon Hoon, the lead singer of Blind Melon, until the day he died.
content: The musician Shannon Hoon, who died in 1995 of complications from a drug overdose at the age of 28, was an inveterate self-chronicler. The documentary “All I Can Say” credits Hoon as one of four directors and was assembled from video footage he recorded from 1990 until mere hours before his death. It chronicles, among other things, the rise and decline of his band Blind Melon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: A Suicide, an App and a Time for a Reckoning
description: Companies like the stock-trading app Robinhood can seem not just careless but also predatory.
content: I spent a lot of time this week trying to come up with the best way to get those who make things in Silicon Valley to better understand the suicide of Alex Kearns, a student at the University of Nebraska. He killed himself after he mistakenly believed that he had a $730,000 negative balance on the millennial-popular Robinhood app, which he had downloaded to learn about investing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek, Peter Eavis and Kate Kelly
title: Fed Limits Bank Payouts and Suspends Share Buybacks as Pandemic Grinds On
description: About a quarter of banks would near minimum capital levels in a double dip recession, the Fed said, as it announced its stress-test results.
content: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Thursday temporarily restricted shareholder payouts by the nation’s biggest banks, barring them from buying back their own stocks or increasing dividend payments in the third quarter as regulators try to ensure banks remain strong enough to keep lending through the pandemic-induced downturn.
source.name: The New York Times

content: I have lived on both sides of American inequality. I began life in the bottom 1 percent but found my way to the top. And I know, all too personally, that the distance between the two never has been greater.

content: During a normal week, Jordan Pavlin, the editorial director at Knopf, seldom ate at her desk. title: ‘Gone With the Wind’ Returns to HBO Max With a Few Additions
description: There is now a video intro discussing the film’s much-criticized depictions of the South and politicianry, and a panel discussion examining those issues further.
content: When HBO Max removed the Oscar-winning 1939 adaptation of Margaret Mitchell’s “Gone With the Wind” from its streaming catalog earlier this month, the service promised that the film would return, albeit with “a discussion of its historical context.” On Wednesday, the film quietly resumed its place in that library, and the streamer made good on its promise with two noteworthy additions.

description: HBO’s “I’ll Be Gone in the Dark” tells the intertwined stories of the Golden State Killer and Michelle McNamara, the true-crime writer who felt she was born to unmask him.

title: ‘The Audition’ Review: A Violin Teacher on the Verge
description: She’s not happy, and her student isn’t laughing, either. Nina Hoss is impeccable in this film by Ina Weisse.
content: This picture kicks off with a scene we may think we’ve seen many times: a tryout at a prestigious music school. A group of exacting adults assesses a series of young classical players; we may think the aspiring ones sound OK or better, but the grown-ups are brutal. It’s their job to be, and their ears are trained to be.

author: By Kyle Turner
title: ‘My Spy’ Review: A Secret Agent Gets Outsmarted
description: Dave Bautista bumbles as a C.I.A. field agent, and has a 9-year-old help him along the way.
content: In the kind of movie “My Spy” is, comedy is derived from fish-out-of-water scenarios. The flailing fish here is the burly, physically adept C.I.A. field agent JJ (Dave Bautista), who is demoted and left gallivanting around the schoolyard with the 9-year-old girl, Sophie (Chloe Coleman). The plan is to nab Sophie’s nefarious uncle, Marquez (Greg Bryk), who is on the brink of selling nuclear weapons plans to another terrorist. There are pratfalls and dodge ball along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Another Nightmare Video and the Police on the Defensive in Tucson
description: A city with a relatively progressive image and reform-minded police is grappling with a brutal death in police custody — and why it took so long to become public.
content: It was another gruesome video of policing in America — a naked Latino man, his face covered by a mesh spit guard, his hands cuffed behind him as he lay dying face down on the ground at his grandmother’s house. He pleaded for water more than a dozen times, saying he could not breathe as police officers restrained his legs and torso.
source.name: The New York Times

content: “The Last Tree,” the visually arresting second feature from Shola Amoo, offers a coming-of-age narrative guided by fluid definitions of family, strains of cultural tension and the quest for personal freedom.

author: By Deb Amlen
